executive_summary: Emergency veterinary services provide care to livestock, equines and domesticated animals. As pet insurance coverage has soared, animal care utilization has increased, raising demand for emergency veterinary services and boosting revenue growth. Strong wage growth in the years immediately preceding the pandemic boosted per capita disposable income. This enabled households to spend more on laboratory tests and other forms of treatment when they took their pets to their local clinic, raising demand for the industry's services. Individuals didn't go out much during the pandemic since stadiums, businesses, bars and other establishments were closed, so people became very lonely. Loneliness increased the number of pets, which increased spending on emergency veterinary visits and caused revenue to rise in 2020.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Soaring Demand for Pet Insurance Has Been a Boon for the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As interest rates have increased, it's become more expensive for farmers to afford essential equipment. They've rationed veterinary services to pay for farm equipment and barns, so demand for the industry's services from livestock has declined in 2022, causing revenue to also fall. Overall, revenue for emergency veterinary service providers is anticipated to surge at a CAGR of 5.6% during the current period, reaching $14.0 billion in 2023. Revenue is expected to increase 5.4% in that year.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: High Wages in the Pre-Pandemic Economy Have Raised Spending on Veterinary Care
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The US economy was in a long-term expansion in the late 2010s, as it was in the final stages of recovery from the financial crisis of 2008. Soaring GDP growth enabled corporate profit to rise, boosting wage growth. Since consumers had higher incomes, they were willing to allocate more resources toward healthcare for their pets, raising demand for veterinary services. Although households seeking emergency veterinary services need the care for their pets, higher incomes enable these individuals to spend more on extraneous services (e.g., laboratory tests) than they otherwise would have if they had less money, so rising wages still benefited this industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Loneliness Was a Major Problem During COVID-19
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: When the pandemic hit, state and local governments forced nonessential businesses to shut down and individuals were advised to stay at home as much as possible to reduce the risk of spreading or catching the virus. Since people were mostly stuck at home and interaction with other humans outside was limited, loneliness soared during the pandemic. To cope with being alone, many individuals purchased pets. When the number of pets rose, animal health issues increased, boosting demand for emergency veterinary services and raising revenue in 2020. When the economy opened up during the pandemic recovery, individuals could interact with other humans more readily again, so demand for pets declined, constraining revenue growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Higher Interest Rates Have Constrained Farmers' Incomes
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As inflation has soared, the Federal Reserve has been increasing interest rates to bring down rising prices. The higher cost of borrowing has made it more difficult for farmers to purchase equipment, rent barns and pay for some materials. Farmers must purchase equipment and other essential materials, so they've been cutting out extraneous parts of their budget to cope with higher interest rates. While veterinary care for livestock is essential for farmers, it's not as vital as equipment, so they've been using first-aid instead of going to the vet to treat their farm animals. Since first-aid is a substitute for emergency veterinary services, higher interest rates have contributed to declining revenue recently.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The US Economy Will Be Strong
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite current economic challenges related to high inflation, rising interest rates and recessionary fears, GDP is expected to rise steadily during the outlook period. Consistent economic growth will boost consumer spending and corporate profit, making wage growth robust. Rising wages will cause per capita disposable income to increase, enabling households to purchase a slew of extra goods and services. Since individuals have more money, they'll be willing to spend more on helping their pet during an emergency visit to the veterinarian. Consumers will also refrain from applying first-aid to their livestock and pets to save money, so they'll decide to go to their local animal doctor instead. These factors will aid revenue growth during the outlook period.

The number of pets fell recently as individuals satisfied their need for cats and dogs during the pandemic. Demand for pets will display a resurgence during the outlook period, as it will continue to become commonplace for a family to have a cat, dog or another type of domesticated animal. The number of households will increase as the population rises. More families create more demand for pets. Higher incomes will also encourage households to get a cat or a dog, as they can more easily afford a pet with more money coming in. When families have more pets, the total number of health issues animals face rises, increasing spending on emergency veterinary services and boosting revenue during the outlook period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Clinics Will Increasingly Adopt New Treatments for Animals
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: To compete with other practices, veterinary clinics will start to offer treatments previously used only for humans. Practices will use laser technology more readily, making cutting more precise. The treatment reduces bleeding, tissue damage and helps animals heal faster, so employing laser technology will make veterinary clinics more attractive to customers. Veterinarians will also start to use endoscopy on animals. Endoscopy enables doctors to see internal organs without surgery by inserting a long and flexible tube into a pet's body. Endoscopy will enable veterinarians to treat some animal health issues much more painlessly and quickly, increasing the number of customers clinics can see within a specific time period. These new treatments will raise efficiency for veterinary practices, increasing revenue for the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Opposition to Pet Breeding Will Hurt the Industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Dog and pet breeding is often cruel to animals, so animal rights groups have successfully lobbied the government to regulate the industry. The Animal Welfare Act (AWA) requires breeders that sell more than 25 animals per year to receive a license, imposing a heavy barrier to entry on the industry. Animal rights groups will continue to push for more regulations and raise awareness about the cruelty of dog and pet breeding. These efforts will put breeders out of business, so revenue for pet and dog breeders will fall during the outlook period. Since animal breeding will decline, the number of pets will fall, reducing demand for emergency veterinary services and constraining revenue for the industry.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry provide emergency veterinary services to livestock, equines and domesticated animals.

threats: Demand from dog and pet breeders

key_trends: As technological advancements in healthcare have taken place, procedures originally done on humans have become commonplace for animals, raising the price of veterinary care.
Elevated prices for veterinary services have caused many households to take out insurance policies for their pets.
Since insurance has significantly reduced out-of-pocket costs for pet owners, they're more likely to go to an emergency veterinary clinic instead.

market_segmentation.segment_description: More than three-quarters of emergency veterinary service providers exclusively or predominantly serve pets such as cats and dogs.
Nearly one-tenth of veterinary clinics serve equines and mixed animals (e.g., small critters).
Emergency veterinary practices primarily catering to food animals treat cattle, sheep, goats, chickens, turkey, pigs and other livestock animals.

products_and_services.product_description: Nonsurgical procedures comprise more than half of revenue and include many different procedures. Central line replacement puts a catheter into an animal's central vein.
Diagnostic tests such as echocardiography, ultrasonography and radiography to animals.

tier_1_suppliers: Commercial Building Construction in the US
Electric Power Transmission in the US
Medical Instrument & Supply Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing in the US
Organic Chemical Manufacturing in the US
Medical Supplies Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_buyers: Hog & Pig Farming in the US
Horse & Other Equine Production in the US
Beef Cattle Production in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand for surgical treatments is dependent on the number of pets
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Surgical procedures for animals comprise more than one-fifth of revenue.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast comprises the largest share of the United States population.
The Rocky Mountains region has a low population but a massive amount of land area.
Since the Plains states contain many farms, many livestock is used to graze the land.
The Mid-Atlantic region contains large, densely populated cities.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Veterinarians must have completed a graduate degree and obtain a license before commencing practice.
For veterinarians abroad seeking to work in the United States, obtaining a license also involves registration, passing a national board examination and demonstrating proficiency in English.
Some states prohibit business corporations from providing veterinary medical care.
Many emergency veterinary clinics shut down when the pandemic began.

basis_points.basis_description: Since many clinics exist, there's significant internal competition among emergency veterinary service providers.
While emergency veterinary services are essential for many pet owners, there are several substitutes.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Small Clinics Have a Reputation in Their Local Communities
concentration_points.concentration_description: Pet owners and farmers often travel to their local clinics to receive care for their pets and livestock.
Specialization enables veterinarians to offer the best high-quality services to an owner of a specific animal.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases include medications, vaccinations, splints, casts and disposable examination instruments
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases include medications, vaccinations, splints, casts and disposable examination instruments used in emergency animal care.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Employees Have Been Demanding Higher Pay Amid Soaring Inflation
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Employees can threaten to go to other clinics if their pay isn't increased.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Miscellaneous Costs Have Been Crowded Out By Other Categories
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Miscellaneous costs include insurance, legal fees, contracted labor, research and development (R&D) expenditure and IT services.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: While entrants must pay for some capital costs (e.g., medicine, equipment)
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: While entrants must pay for some capital costs, labor poses a much larger barrier to entry.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Households value their pets, so demand for emergency care tends to be pretty inelastic.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The Level of Income Influences Spending on Emergency Veterinary Services
volatility_points.volatility_description: Since spending on emergency veterinary services doesn't shift much with economic conditions, revenue volatility is relatively muted.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Demand for surgical treatments is dependent on the number of pets
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Surgical procedures for animals comprise more than one-fifth of revenue.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Nonsurgical treatments have become more affordable for veterinarians
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Nonsurgical procedures comprise more than half of revenue.
Emergency veterinary service providers offer diagnostic tests such as echocardiography, ultrasonography and radiography to animals.

FAQs.question: How much does your company allocate to marketing expenses?
FAQs.answer: Typically, less than 1.0 - 2.0% of revenue is allocated to marketing expenses.

FAQs.question: How does your company strategically locate to ensure a flow of customers?
FAQs.answer: Proximity to an area with a high level of pet ownership and income is significant to ensure a flow of customers.

FAQs.question: How can you encourage annual visits from low-income families?
FAQs.answer: Offering payment plans is one way to provide incentive for lower income families to invest in preventative healthcare visits for their companion animal.

FAQs.question: What are your main sources of competition?
FAQs.answer: Location, hours of operation, the range of services offered, the quality of care, fee rates and programs and systems to promote recommendations or referrals are the primary sources of competition.

FAQs.question: How has technological change improved the accuracy of your practice's diagnostics?
FAQs.answer: There's a migration of areas of human testing into the veterinary field, helping drive growth in animal laboratory testing revenue.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in new and sophisticated technology?
FAQs.answer: The technology used in this industry includes equipment such as pathology equipment, CT scanning technology, 3D printing, ultra-sound, MRI, x-ray machines, anesthetic machines, drugs and others.

FAQs.question: Is your practice subject to state regulation?
FAQs.answer: The industry is subject to significant state-based regulation and restrictions on operations.

FAQs.question: Do you work with industry associations or other groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: The American Veterinary Medical Association (AVMA) is the largest organization that lobbies for veterinary interests.

FAQs.question: How much does your practice expend on depreciation expenses?
FAQs.answer: Typically, depreciation accounts for 1.0% - 2.0% of total revenue.

FAQs.question: How does your profit compare to your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Typically, profit comprises nearly or slightly greater than 10.0% of revenue.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted?
FAQs.answer: The rate of technology change in the industry is quick.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets?
FAQs.answer: Proximity to an area with a high level of pet ownership and income is significant to ensure a flow of customers.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation among customers?
FAQs.answer: Most clients pay for veterinary services out of pocket.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your services are administered to livestock?
FAQs.answer: As the threat of disease in livestock rises, so does demand for veterinary care.

FAQs.question: Does your company have plans to invest in any new technology?
FAQs.answer: Technological change enables veterinary medicine to encompass more treatments.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your revenue is derived from emergency services for cats and dogs?
FAQs.answer: As the number of domesticated cats and dogs increases, so does demand for emergency veterinary services.
